Great lecture!!! David Jerison at x2!!! Thanks to MIT and David Jerison.
25:18 it was indeed a great question 🤣

A small comment on the last problem:  I think it could be much easier to calculate by just switching the axes. Y-axis would become the X-axis, but in the opposite direction(meaning +y would be -x) and the X-axis would become the Y-axis. This way it is much easier.   That is basically what the method 2 does, but in a complicated manner. Idk, maybe solving the problem that way is useful, because switching the axes is not always possible. I am not sure, that is just the way I solved the problem.  One other important thing about this way is that you can easily see why it is "right - left", it is just because "right" becomes the upper(greater) part when you switch the axes.
It is wonderful that this professor can introduce the history in an inspiring way without disrupting the flow of the instruction.
Erf 😂

At 42:59, while deciding the height of rectangle in an interval with x varying from 0 to 1, shouldnt we add the height of rectangle above or below the x axis? Why did we subtract?

One day Lord Kelvin asked his students: what is a mathematician? Then he wrote on the blackboard the integral from minus infinity to plus infinity of e^-x^2 and added: a mathematician is the one who writes next to this integral the square root of pi without even thinking about it!

We subtract the value of the upper function from that of the lower one.  In a geometrical sense what you are doing is, you are taking the area of the space under the upper curve and then subtracting from it the value of the lower curve, so that you get the area in between.  And as you said we end up adding the heights of the rectangle below and above the x axis because the value of the lower function is always negative and something minus a negative value amounts to a plus sign.

I think intuitively (right - left) is due to the direction of the axis. Like top is always larger than bottom, the positive direction for the horizontal axis is set from left to the right, hence numbers on the right are larger. it might be an easier way to see this.

I finally understand that lecture clearly.  That is beginning of Calculus 2 because fist half of semester covers entire Calculus 1.  I took Calculus 2 (MAT 205) at Gallaudet University but professor did not teach clearly and I failed course.  I re-took Calculus 2 with different professor and finally passed a course.  That is great lectures!!  Thanks, MIT!

For the last part, why is it (right - left)? It is because the Method 2, setting the limit section on y-axis and evaluating the change of x-axis. That means (y+2)-(y^2) = dx.     From the x-axis perspective, the x value from straight line (x=y+2) is definitely greater than the  x value from Arc BC (x=y^2).   Or you can just simply draw a line e.g. y=1(horizontal line).  You will know the x value from straight line> x value from Arc BC
